questions.text: A 25-year-old man who is a professional body builder presents with abdominal pain and new-onset jaundice. Exam reveals scleral icterus and hepatomegaly with abdominal tenderness. Abdominal ultrasound shows hepatomegaly but is otherwise unremarkable. A Liver biopsy shows multiple blood-filled cysts (see figure). What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution: Peilosis hepatis is a relatively rare condition associated with the presence of large blood-filled cavities on histological examination of the liver. Associated conditions include infection with HIV, Bartonella, renal transplantation, and use of anabolic steroids. The histopathology slide shows the typical enlarged blood-filled cyst surrounded by interrupted hepatocyte plates and sinusoid walls, which is typical of this condition.

choices.text: Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is admitted from the emergency department with upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis but felt well until early this morning when he had hematemesis. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy in the emergency department showed large esophageal varices, which were ligated. He currently feels weak but has had no other complaints. Physical examination findings include the following: blood pressure 120/60 mm Hg, heart rate 82 beats per minute, alert and oriented, splenomegaly, and no ascites or edema. Laboratory study results are as follows: hemoglobin 10.2 g/L, platelet count 65x109/L, aspartate aminotransferase 84 U/L, alanine aminotransferase 75 U/L, total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dL, albumin 3.0 g/dL, and international normalized ratio 1.2. Abdominal ultrasonography shows no liver mass, a patent portal vein, splenomegaly, and no ascites. Which of the following would you advise now?
questions.solution: Patients with cirrhosis who are admitted with gastro- intestinal tract bleeding should receive prophylactic antibiotics even if there is no ascites. Oral norfloxacin is probably sufficient, although a recent trial suggested that a third-generation cephalosporin may be more effective if there is a high prevalence of quinolone resistance. Much of the recent reduction in mortality related to variceal bleed- ing is probably due to the increasing use of prophylactic antibiotics in patients with cirrhosis and gastrointestinal tract bleeding. Transjugular intrahepatic portal systemic shunt is not necessary unless bleeding cannot be controlled with endoscopy or medical therapy. Although the hemoglobin level should be carefully monitored, the patient is hemodynamically stable and does not need transfusion now. Overtransfusion, when hemoglobin is greater than 8 to 9 g/dL, can precipitate recurrence of bleeding and fluid overload. Fresh frozen plasma is also not necessary since the INR is relatively normal. A decision about pegylated interferon and ribavirin treatment of hepatitis C should be deferred until the patient has recovered from this bleeding episode.

questions.text: A 45 year old female was diagnosed by a gastroenterologist to be a case of primary biliary cirrhosis. What is the medical treatment that will be instituted ?
questions.solution:
Though a variety of therapies have been proposed, UDCA is the only approved treatment that has some degree of efficacy by slowing the rate of progression of the disease.

PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS

  • Strong female preponderance.
  • Median age at diagnosis is 50 years.
  • Cause is unknown.
  • Pathology
    • Portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium
      sized bile ducts.
    • Earliest lesion is “chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis”
  • Clinical features
    • Most patients are asymptomatic.
    • Severe fatigue.
    • Debilitating pruritus. Pruritus that presents prior to the development of jaundice indicates severe disease and poor prognosis.
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly, Splenomegaly, Ascites and Edema.
    • Hyperpigmentation, Xanthelasma, Xanthomata (due to altered cholesterol metabolism)
    • Bone pain resulting from osteopenia or osteoporosis.
  • Lab findings
    • Cholestatic pattern with elevated GGT and ALP.
    • Immunoglobulins, particularly IgM are typically increased.
    • Hyperbilirubinemia (once cirrhosis has developed).
    • Thrombocytopenia, Leukopenia and Anaemia (in patients with portal hypertension and hypersplenism).
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 90% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Upto 10% of patients with characteristic PBC have features of Autoimmune hepatitis as well and are defined as having “overlap” syndrome.
  • TREATMENT : UDCA is the only approved treatment.
  • Improves both biochemical and histological features of the disease.
  • Slows the rate of progression of PBC, but it does not reverse or cure the disease.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with end-stage liver disease from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis presents with dyspnea and a large right-sided pleural effusion. This is his third presentation with a large right-sided effusion in the past 6 months. On examination, the patient has tense ascites, spider nevi, and gynecomastia. On thoracentesis, he again has a pale-yellow, clear fluid with pH 7.4, glucose 100 mg/dL, protein 1.2 g/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 60 U/L. Lipid analysis results are normal. On a previous workup, the patient had a normal echocardiogram, normal renal function, and normal thyrotropin level. What is the likely cause of this patient's effusion?
questions.solution: The presentation is consistent with hepatic hydrothorax (recurrent large transudative pleural effusions in a patient with cirrhosis and no alternative explanation). Hepatic hydrothorax occurs predominantly on the right side and is transudative. Treatment is focused on controlling the ascites, which can become an intractable problem. The normal echocardiogram excludes congestive heart failure. Hypoalbuminemia-related effusions are typically bilateral with associated anasarca. Chylothorax is unlikely given the normal results from lipid analysis of the pleural fluid.

choices.text: Multiple hamartomatous polyps in small bowel and colon
The gene STK 11 on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients
Malignant change in polyps is rare

questions.text: All are true about Peutz-Jegher's syndrome except :
questions.solution:
PEUTZ-JEGHERS SYNDROME

  1. Autosomal dominant disease characterised by melanosis of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous (benign tumour-like malformation resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.
  2. Melanin spots can also occur on the digits and perianal skin.
  3. Gene STK11 on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients with this condition.
  4. Malignant change in the polyps rarely occurs and, in general the polyps can be left alone.
  5. Resection may be indicated for heavy and persistent or recurrent bleeding or intussusception.
  6. Polyps may be removed by enterotomy, or, at laparotomy, snared via a colonoscope introduced via an enterotomy.
  7. Heavily involved segments of small intestine may occasionally be resected.

questions.text: The image shows the endoscopic picture of a 73 year old male admitted for evaluation of GI bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) syndrome, also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly is characterized endoscopically by 'watermelon stripes'.

choices.text: May be familial or associated with Down's syndrome
Gene mutations have been identified on chromosome 10 and 13 in some patients

questions.text: All are true about Hirschsprung's disease EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
HIRSCHSPRUNG’S DISEASE

  • Characterised by :
    • Congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells (Aganglionosis)
    • Presence of hypertrophic nerves in the distal large bowel
  • Absence of ganglion cells is due to a failure of migration of vagal neural crest cells into the developing gut.
  • Affected gut is in spasm causing a functional bowel obstruction.
  • Aganglionosis is restricted to the rectum and sigmoid colon in 75 per cent of patients (short segment), involves the proximal colon in 15 per cent (long segment) and affects the entire colon and a portion of terminal ileum in 10 per cent (total colonic aganglionosis).
  • A transition zone exists between the dilated, proximal, normally innervated bowel and the narrow, distal aganglionic segment.
  • May be familial or associated with Down syndrome or other genetic disorders.
  • Gene mutations have been identified on chromosome 10 (involving the RET proto-oncogene) and on chromosome 13 in some patients.
  • Typically presents in the neonatal period with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension and bilious vomiting, but it may not be diagnosed until later in childhood or even adult life, when it manifests as severe chronic constipation.
  • Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication of the disease.
  • Diagnosis requires an adequate rectal biopsy and an experienced pathologist.
  • A contrast enema may show the narrow aganglionic segment, a cone and the dilated proximal bowel.

Surgery aims to remove the aganglionic segment and ‘pull-through’ ganglionic bowel to the anus (e.g. Swenson, Duhamel, Soave and transanal procedures).

questions.text: Serology profile done for a patient is mentioned below. What is the likely cause of the abnormal findings.
questions.solution:
• Precore-mutant: variety of Hepatitis B virus that does not produce Hepatitis B virus e antigen (HbeAg). Infections produced by mutants are difficult to treat and cause disease long duration with increased risk of transformation to cirrhosis and malignancy
  • Escape mutant: mutation in HBsAg preventing them from being neutralized by anti-HBsAG antibody, hence vaccination not effective; seen in infants born to HBeAg positive mothers; liver transplant recipients who have received combined immunisation

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with history of alcohol-induced cirrhosis is admitted to the hospital for treatment of cellulitis. He has a history of ascites and edema that has been relatively well controlled with a low sodium diet and diuretic therapy. At admission his abdomen is soft with flank fullness and shifting dullness. He has 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. Twice daily intravenous furosemide is started for diuresis. Vancomycin is started for cellulitis, and the patient improves. On hospital day 5, his creatinine is found to double to 2.6 mg/dL. What is the most likely etiology for his kidney injury?
questions.solution: This patient, who was given multiple doses of intra- venous furosemide, should be evaluated for diuretic- induced azotemia. Intravenous furosemide should be avoided in patients with cirrhosis. While effective for diuresis in heart failure, intravenous furosemide can rapidly lead to azotemia that can be confused with hepatorenal syndrome type 1. Hepatorenal syndrome type 2 does not present this acutely. Acute tubular necrosis is less likely in this clinical scenario. This patient's renal dysfunction may be reversed with intravenous fluids and discontinuation of diuretics.

questions.text: In a patient with jaundice, absence of urobilinogen indicates:
questions.solution:
Types of Jaundice



  • Jaundice becomes clinically evident with serum bilirubin >2 mg/dl
  • Acholuric jaundice: Bilirubin is unconjugated and hence not excreted in urine
  • Delta bilirubin: bilirubin covalently linked to albumin
  • In unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bilirubin tightly bound to albumin, not excreted in urine, kernicterus can occur and gives indirect positive Van den Bergh reaction
  • In conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bilirubin is water soluble, loosely bound to albumin and gives a direct positive Van den Bergh reaction

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is referred to the GI clinic for management of anemia and occasional melena. On physical examination, she appears pale but in no acute distress. Examination of the lips is shown in the figure. Labs show a hemoglobin of 6.9 g/dL; ferritin of 6 ng/mL; and serum iron of 34 μg/dL. Which of the following is most likely found on examination of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution: The patient has recurrent GI bleeding and multiple telangiectasias of the lip and vermillion border consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler Weber-Rendu disease). Vascular malformations occur in the GI tract, liver, lungs, central nervous system, and genitourinary tract. Patients with Peutz- Jeghers syndrome have multiple mucocutaneous melanocytic macules that can appear on the lips, but they do not have telangiectasias as shown in the figure. These patients have multiple hamartomatous polyps throughout the GI tract. There is no reason for this patient to have an increased risk of adenomatous polyps, carcinoid tumors, or GIST.

questions.text: In a patient with history of halothane hepatotoxicity, the anesthesia team is deciding upon which agent to use to give him the lowest risk of hepatotoxicity. Which of the following is associated with the least incidence of hepato- toxicity in this patient?
questions.solution: The extent to which haloalkane anesthetics are metabolized by CYP enzymes predicts the likelihood of liver injury. Halothane is metabolized 20% to 30%, methoxyflurane 30%, enflurane 2%, sevoflurane 1%, isoflurane 0.2%, and desflurane less than 0.2%

questions.text: Your patient is a 5-year-old boy with bloody diarrhoea for the past 2 days accompanied by fever to 40°C and vomiting. He has a pet corn snake. Blood culture and stool culture from the boy and stool culture from the snake revealed the same organism. The cultures grew a gram-negative rod that produced colourless colonies on EMB agar. Which one of the following bacteria is the most likely cause of this infection?
questions.solution: The epidemiology of Salmonella infections is related to the ingestion of food and water contaminated by human and animal wastes. S. typhi, the cause of typhoid fever, is transmitted only by humans, but all other species have a significant animal as well as human reservoir. Human sources are either persons who temporarily excrete the organism during or shortly after an attack of enterocolitis or chronic carriers who excrete the organism for years. The most frequent animal source is poultry and eggs, but meat products that are inadequately cooked have been implicated as well. Dogs and other pets, including turtles, snakes, lizards, and iguanas, are additional sources.

choices.text: IgM antibody to hepatitis A virus

questions.text: Your patient is a 35-year-old man who complains that the whites of his eyes have turned yellow. After taking a history and doing a physical, you order serologic tests to determine whether he has viral hepatitis. On the basis of the results, you tell him that he has a mild form of hepatitis that does not cause long-term damage to the liver. Your conclusion is based on a positive result on which one of the following tests?
questions.solution: Most HAV infections are asymptomatic and are detected by the presence of IgM, IgG antibodies. No chronic hepatitis or chronic carrier state occurs, and there is no predisposition to hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 74 yr old male, complained of severe vomiting for past 3 days. History reveals he is a known case of parkinson's and is currently on treatment for it. He was given an anti-emetic and his symptoms were resolved. The most probable mechanism of action of that anti-emetic would be.
questions.solution: This patient complained of vomiting which was primarily due to D2 receptor activation present in CTZ as the patient was treated with levodopa (Drug used for parkinson’s). So, preferentially a D2 receptor blocker is preferred as 5-HT3 antagonist is ineffective in this patient.

questions.text: The small bowel chloride channel activator used in treatment of idiopathic constipation is

choices.text: Combination has bactericidal effect on H.pylori
Both drugs tend to cause less toxicity when given together
To avoid food and drug interaction

questions.text: A 55 yrs old female complained of burning sensation in abdomen immediately after taking food. To avoid the symptoms, the physician prescribed antacid gel which contains a mixture of aluminium hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide. What is the rationale behind this combination?
questions.solution: Aluminium causes constipation and magnesium causes diarrhea. By giving both drugs in combination, the GI motility adverse effects can be minimalized.

questions.text: A 65 yr old male with complaints of idiopathic constipation was prescribed a laxative which acts in colon by increasing absorption of water into fecal content and thereby promotes peristalsis after 1-2 days of therapy. What might be the probable drug?
questions.solution:
Methylcellulose is an indigestible hydrophilic polysaccharide polymer that absorbs water, forming a bulky gel that distends the intestine, thus stimulating peristaltic activity.

It acts mainly in the colon and takes 1 or 2 days to work.

The laxative effect is mild.

The others acts at the small intestine

questions.text: A 56 yr old female with complaints of hematochezia was admitted for colonoscopy. It showed a pigmentation as shown in the image. History reveals that she is taking an over the counter laxative for her constipation. Which of the following drugs would cause this sign depicted in the image?
questions.solution: Senna, on chronic use, is associated with black pigmentation in colon named as ‘Melanosis coli’.

questions.text: Famotidine, a H2 blocker, is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following best explains its mechanism of action in the absence of histamine release?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of Famotidine:

  1. In presence of histamine -> Competitive antagonist
  2. In absence of histamine -> Inverse agonist

questions.text: Which of the following drugs tend to stimulate cytotoxic lymphocyte response directed at hepatocyte cell membrane thereby causes an immune mediated damage to the liver?
questions.solution:
Nitrofurantoin -> Immune mediated hepatocellular reaction

Amiodarone -> Steatohepatitis

Oral contraceptives -> Encourages tumor formation

Erythromycin -> Cholestasis

questions.text: A known case metastatic ovarian carcinoma was complained of severe nausea and vomiting following a sitting with cisplatin. A dose of Palonosteron + Dexamethasone + Netupitant was administered and found to be ineffective. What might be the next step in management?
questions.solution: Dronabinol is a cannabinoid receptor agonist and serves as an antiemetic. Due to availability of many other better anti-emetics, this is rarely used nowadays, but can be used as an additive for resistant chemotherapy induced emesis.

questions.text: A known asthmatic was on treatment with inhaled albuterol and oral theophylline. He reported to the emergency with complaints of nervousness, insomnia and palpitations. History reveals he has taken a drug for burning sensation in stomach from a nearby pharmacy. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution: Cimetidine, a H2 blocker, is a known drug to cause microsomal inhibition. When this drug was given in this patient who is already on a narrow therapeutic index drug, theophylline, it caused accumulation of theophylline leading onto toxicity.

questions.text: A 40 years old male with dysphagia of Solids and Liquids with symptoms regurgitation and chest pain and weight loss. Which of the following is the preferred investigation to diagnose this?
questions.solution:
• IOC for Achalasia Cardia= Manometry.
  • Barium swallow and X ray can help in added points on this case.
  • Endoscopy is not always preferred, it must be done if you suspect malignancy as one cause of narrowing in lower end.

Ref. Page 1070, Bailey and Love 27th edition

choices.text: He is frustrated with delay of patient >24 hours to operate
Patient needs urgent laparotomy and closure of perforation
On Thoracotomy if bed is healthy we can do primary repair
Patient has Mackler's triad on History and examination

questions.text: 25 years old male having a binge drink with his friends suddenly vomited, following which he developed chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema and collapsed. he is shifted to a tertiary centre after resuscitation in a local hospital for 1 day. On receiving the patient the surgical gastroenterologist got frustrated with delay from the previous hospital and he shifted the patient to theatre immediately. Which of the following statement is false
questions.solution:
• This is a case of Boerhaave Syndrome, with rupture of esophagus intra thoracic most commonly in lower left posterior esophagus.
  • This case will need an emergency Thoracotomy in < 24 hours.
  • The surgeon gets frustrated because of the delay made by the primary physician, because mortality is very high if delay >24 hours.
  • The ideal treatment for unhealthy bed is Esophagostomy+ ICD and a FJ tube,

choices.text: Advise him to undergo CECT abdomen
EUS will confirm the diagnosis now

questions.text: 70 years old male Mr.Ramu presented with complaints of Early satiety and occasional vomiting. He gives H/o weight loss in past 6 months and melena on and off. On Examination you can see a visible fullness in epigastrium with a movement from upper left to right side. He is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. Hb- 5.6 gm/dl. You decide to evaluate him. What will be the ideal next step in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Patient is having GOO features with VGP, such patients must be immediately checked for electrolyte imbalance and correction of the electrolyte anomaly is urgent priority.
  • Fluid of choice is NS+ potassium supplement (RL is contraindicated in due to aggravation of alkalosis which can happen due to conversion of lactate to bicarbonate in Liver)

choices.text: Technetium 99m scan is used for diagnosis

questions.text: All are true about Retained Antrum Syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Retained Antrum Syndrome:

  • A complication following Billroth 2 Reconstruction, in which part of antrum and pylorus is left along with the duodenum.


  • The antrum now seen in continuity with duodenum is in continuous exposure to alkaline Bile and pancreatic secretions and hence there is an excess production of Gastrin (Gastrin producing G cells are stimulated by alkaline medium)
  • Increased Gastrin produces severe hypergastrinemia induced Ulcer in the remaining part of proximal stomach.
  • This complication is very common after Billroth II
  • Billroth 1 operation will not have such complications.

Management:

  • Serum Gastrin levels increases to the extent of Zollinger Ellison Syndrome, the only way to differentiate from ZES is by Secretin Stimulation test will not cause increase in Gastrin in Retained Antrum Syndrome as seen in ZES.
  • The disease may respond to PPI , but definitive treatment is re resection of retained antrum.
  • Tc 99m Scan is the IOC to detect the retained Antrum**
  • Secretin Stimulation test is positive for ZES but negative for Retained Antrum Syndrome.
  • Similarly there is Calcium Provocation test is also positive only for ZES and negative for all other cases of Hypergastrinemia like Retained Antrum Syndrome, Gastric Outlet Obstruction and Chronic Renal failures.

Ref. Internet Sources

questions.text:
A patient who underwent Sleeve gastrectomy 10 days back is readmitted with fever and abdominal pain. What is the inference?
1- Upto 30 days there is chances of leak from Angle of His
2- Patients deteriorate rapidy due to sepsis
3- Xray abdomen erect is the best investigation
4- In case of doubt of leak, even relaparoscopy is advised
questions.solution:
• In sleeve gastrectomy, a staple line leak at the angle of His usually presents any time after discharge up to 30 days, and patients can also deteriorate rapidly with sepsis.
  • Urgent CT scanning and relaparoscopy are indicated, with source control by drainage the major goal

Ref Bailey and Love 27th edition page 1150

choices.text: A sausage shape mass is palpated near umbilicus
PR shows Red currant jelly stool

questions.text: 1 year old baby presents with history of vomiting past 1 day. It's a bilious vomiting. Baby's mother says that she is crying constantly and not feeding past 1 day. She gives a history that baby passes Red currant color jelly stools on and off. On evaluation of this baby- which is false statement
questions.solution:
• Classical question on Intussusception.
    IOC is USG which shows Target sign/Bull’s eye sign or Pseudokidney sign
  • CT abdomen can be done , but not the IOC

choices.text: Strong's procedure(Gastrojejunostomy) is the preferred treatment
Angle between SMA and Aorta is between 38 and 65 degree due to mesenteric pad of fat
There is an abrupt cutoff in third part of duodenum during barium study
Third part of duodenum most commonly affected

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about superior mesenteric artery syndrome?
questions.solution:
Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome or Wilkie’s syndrome:


  • Compression of 3rd part of duodenum between aorta and SMA leading to duodenal obstruction
  • Most common in young females with anorexia, rapid weight loss, post bariatric surgery due to loss of mesenteric pad of fat that is maintaining the Aortomesenteric angle.
    • /ul>

    • Treatment goal: To improve the narrow AO angle
    • Strong’s procedure (preferred treatment): Mobilization of fourth part of duodenum by dividing ligament of Treitz thereby improving angle, advantage of not needing any anastomoses procedure and early postoperative recovery.
    • Others include: Duodenojejunostomy and Gastrojejunostomy (less preferred)

choices.text: I will advice him to undergo Colonoscopy to take biopsy
Excise the skin lesions as they are premalignant
We have to rule out Liver involvement as there is Jaundice

questions.text: Mr.Vijay singh from Punjab, 40 years age presented to your clinic in Chennai with clinical features of Severe diarrhea past 7 days with occasional Bleeding Per rectum. He tells that he had similar symptoms last month and got treatment in Punjab and got rectified and he didn't bring the records of previous treatment. On further history taking he is telling he is having some skin lesions on his body as shown in the image. On examination in his abdomen nothing significant noted. He is having Hb- 7.5 gm/dl, TC- 18000/mm3, Bilirubin- 2.4 mg/dl. P-ANCA is done is positive for him. What will be wrong statement regarding this patient ?
questions.solution:
• From the History we are clear, this is a case of Ulcerative colitis.
  • The skin lesions shown is known as Pyoderma gangrenosum.
  • These lesions get disappeared after treatment of Ulcerative colitis.
  • No need to do resection, Just steroids alone can make the lesion disappear.
  • The most common extraintestinal manifestation is Hepatic manifestation- FATTY LIVER Seen.
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis produces Jaundice in Ulcerative colitis cases.

choices.text: CEA must be done every 3 months for 2 years.
First Colonoscopy must be done within 6 months as previously no colonoscopy was done
Patient must undertake k-ras mutation study to start mono clonal antibodies
Start her on 6 cycles FOLFOX regimen in post operative period

questions.text: Mrs. Kumari underwent - Right hemicolectomy for Colonic cancer with obstruction as emergency. The surgeon didn't note any metastasis on the liver. The specimen report received shows - growth involving upto muscularis propria, and around 15 nodes are positive. What will not be a part of the post op management protocol?
questions.solution:
Follow up of Colonic cancer is with- '3C'

  • CEA
  • Colonoscopy
  • CECT abdomen

Please note:

  • Only for Stage 4 cancers we must do K ras to decide of monoclonal antibody treatment.
  • Wild Kras cases ( Kras negative) will be treated by Cetuximab and Panitumab
  • If Kras is positive no monoclonal antibodies are goven
  • FOLFOX regimen is used now for Stage 2 and Stage 3 cases*
  • FOLFIRI regimen is used for Stage 4 cases

choices.text: Non operative supportive care is initiated for patients with Cecal diameter <12 cm without ischemia and perforation
Osmotic and Stimulant laxatives are used
Prone positioning and knee chest position encourages passage of flatus
NG tube and Rectal tube are useful

questions.text: Mr Kumar, 78 years old male presented with constipation was diagnosed as Ogilvie syndrome- False statement related to the management is
questions.solution:
• Abdominal tenderness, leukocytosis, fever, and cecal dilation more than 12 cm are signs that may be indicative of colon ischemia, perforation, or impending perforation.
  • Insertion of a nasogastric tube and rectal tube for decompression may be of help.
  • Osmotic and stimulant laxatives should be avoided as they can worsen colonic dilation.
  • Ambulation, prone positioning, and knee-chest position to encourage passage of flatus can assist.
  • Neostigmine is the keystone of pharmacologic decompression therapy.
  • It is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that stimulates the muscarinic receptors and enhances colonic motor activity.
  • Neostigmine is given as a 2 to 2.5 mg IV bolus injected over 3 to 5 minutes
  • 2nd Line treatment; Colonoscopic decompression is considered in patients who have contraindications to Neostigmine or not responsive to Neostigmine.
  • During Colonoscopy- keep a decompression tube.
  • Success rate= 65-95%

Ref. Sabiston 21st edition page 1345

questions.text: Anterior resection is done for a patient with rectal cancer. Post operatively he presents with pain. Biopsy shows involvement of muscular wall but no penetration. Out of the 13 lymph nodes, one is involved. But the high tide lymph node is not involved. Modified duke stage
questions.solution:
Though there were lots of named Colonic Cancer staging used All are replaced by only TNM staging now.

For exam point of view we still read those outdated stagings



  • AC- Astler Coller
  • MAC- Modified AstlerColler
  • N0- Node negative
  • N+- Node positive
  • Remember Stage C means Lymphnode involvement

questions.text: A 25 years old male presents with chronic constipation and acute perianal pain. Pain exacerbates during defecation and associated with fresh bleeding. Abdominal examination is normal. Per rectal examination is not possible due to pain. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The history typical of Acute anal fissure.
  • There will be a breach in anal mucosa at 6’0 clock position distal to dentate line
  • These patients will have severe painful defecation and bleeding after passing motion
  • Various treatment options- Local lignocaine jelly, Diltiazem gel, Oral stool softeners, analgesics.
  • Surgical treatment- Lateral Sphincterotomy

questions.text: A 10-years old female who used to use the swimming pool regularly, comes with a three day history of vomiting, fever and abdominal pain. On examination, abdominal tenderness and guarding are present. The liver dullness is not obliterated. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• The history of a little girl using swimming pool leads us to a diagnose of Respiratory infection which can lead to pneumococcal infection that causes Primary peritonitis.
  • Primary peritonitis is C/B- Vomiting, High grade fever and Abdominal pain.
  • Liver dullness is used to look for Air under diaphragm ( If there is air under diaphragm the liver dullness will not be felt and there will be only resonant note over the liver)
  • Air under diaphragm is a feature of Perforation peritonitis**
  • Primary Pneumococcal peritonitis there will be no air under diaphragm – hence liver dullness will not be obliterated.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with 48 hour history of right upper quadrant pain, dyspnea, non-productive cough, fever with chills and rigor. The pain radiates to right shoulder tip. She has history of perforated duodenal ulcer repair 3 weeks ago. Temperature 39.3°C. O/E there is acute tenderness over right hypochondrium. CXR shows right sided pleural effusion. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Bailey says- 'Pus Nowhere, Pus Some where- search Pus Under the Diaphragm'
  • In a post op case (patient lying)- most dependent site of abscess formation is Subphrenic Space*

questions.text: A patient presents with halitosis and swelling in the left side of neck. On pressing gives gurgling sound. Barium image is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Zenker’s Diverticulum:

  • Mucosal out pouchings through triangular bare area in between upper oblique fibres (Thyropharyngeus) and lower horizontal fibres(cricopharynx) of inferior constrictor muscle of larynx
  • This defect is known as KILIAN’S dehiscence.
  • Due to neuro muscular in co-ordination between two fibres diverticulum occurs.
  • Major etiology seems to be increased pressure in Cricopharynx (Cricopharngeal spasm)hence named as Cricopharyngeal Achalasia
  • SITE- Posterior and middle of neck (posterior triangle swelling)*. More common in left lateral

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with history of peptic ulcer disease was having abdominal pain and distension since many days. It gets worse since last two hours.BP-90/40 and Abdominal radiograph is shown here. What is to be done in this patient ?
questions.solution: • The CXR image shows air under diaphragm suggestive of hollow viscus perforation, And the patient is hypotensive and needs Iv Fluids and Emergency Laprotomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids for 8 months. BMI-18.5, no systemic illness Barium swallow was done and shown below. What other investigations should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical history of dysphagia to both solid and liquids, Barium Image shows bird beak appearance suggestive of Achalasia cardia
  • Gold standard is Manometry and UGIE is done to look for any causes of pseudoachalasia and rule out any malignancy.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in right upper quadrant on fifth post operative day, following Lap Cholecystectomy. She is icteric and On Ultrasound there is collection seen in the Morrison's pouch. Biliary leak is suspected. What is the most sensitive investigation to detect biliary leak
questions.solution:
• Most sensitive investigation for Bile leak is HIDA scan
  • Gold standard to detect anatomical site of leak is ERCP.

questions.text: A 65 year old male with history of recent weight loss undergoes ultrasound Abdomen which shows hypoechoic lesions in the liver surrounded by a halo and on CECT examination the following image is obtained as given below, The lesions do not show significant enhancement on arterial or delayed phase. The Patient is known hypertensive, diabetic and a chronic smoker, what could be the possible diagnosis
questions.solution:
The CECT image shows multiple hypodense lesions which are not enhancing in arterial or delayed phase, in a elderly smoker with recent weight loss suggests secondaries in the liver

Ultrasound shows bulls eye or target like lesions having a hypoechoic halo

  • In HCC, the classic finding on CECT imaging is early arterial enhancement with rapid washout in the portal (venous) and delayed phases.
  • Hemangioma shows initial peripheral nodular enhancement in arterial phase and homogenous centripetal enhancement in delayed phase
  • Carolis disease shows central Dot sign

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic male presents to the emergency with acute onset abdominal pain, mainly in the Rt Upper Quadrant Ultrasound abdomen was done and showed Echogenic foci in the Gall bladder, CT scan was performed and the following image is obtained as shown below, what is the likely cause for this patients symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The Ct scan image shows air in the gallbladder wall in a elderly diabetic patient suggestive of Emphysematous Cholecystitis
  • Emphysematous cholecystitis is a form of acute cholecystitis and a surgical emergency
  • Carries risk of gallbladder gangrene and perforation and high mortality
  • Ultrasonography may demonstrate highly echogenic reflectors with low-level posterior shadowing and reverberation artifacts and champagne sign (echogenic foci rising up from the lumen of Gall bladder )
  • CT is considered the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for identifying gas within the gallbladder lumen or wall
  • HIDA scan may demonstrate the RIM sign

choices.text: Pseudosacculations involving antimesentric side of the bowel
Deep penetrating thorn-like ulcers and fissures in thickened bowel wall

questions.text: A 28 year old female patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea since 5 days. She gives history of similar on and off episodes since two years. She has lost significant weight since then. On examination, she is anemic, has gingivitis and pain and tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, CT scan demonstrated areas of bowel wall thickening with prominent engorged vasa recta in the mesentry, All the following are true about this patients condition except :-
questions.solution:
• The History suggests Inflammatory bowel disease with clues of gingivitis, pain in right lower quadrant(Ileitis) and Comb sign on CT scan (prominent vasa recta) suggests Crohns disease
  • It is charecterised by skip lesions, transmural involvement with fissures, fistulas and longitudinal deep ulcers
  • Ulcerative colitis shows continuous involvement from rectum upwards

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents with acute onset abdominal pain, and an episode of vomiting, He also gives history of recent loss of appetite. The Abdomen is soft but tender especially around the periumbilical region, Ultrasound abdomen is done and the following image obtained is shown. All the following statements are true regarding this condition except?
questions.solution:
• The ultrasound image and the history given point towards Acute Appendicitis in the child
  • On Usg Acute Appendicitis presents as blind ending tubular structure, which is noncompressible, aperistaltic showing luminal diameter more than 6 mm and wall thickening and sometimes a fecolith within

questions.text: Chest Radiograph and Abdominal CT scan of a middle aged male complaining of nagging abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks is given, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: • Calcified Ring like shadow in the region of Liver on Chest Radiograph and the CT scan showing mural calcification is suggestive of Hydatid Cyst and is due to calcification of the Pericyst.

questions.text: A 70 yrs old Patient presented with history of fever, repeated aspiration and coughing in the night. On examination there is a swelling on left side of Neck which produces gurgling sound on compression. Following is the barium swallow study of the patient. What is the most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Zenker’s Diverticulum - patient present with intermittent dysphagia, regurgitation of food and foul smelling breath later on progressive dysphagia progressive. barium study showing midline outpouching.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of saccule it is a diverticulum of mucous membrane which starts from the anterior part of ventricular cavity and extends upward between vestibular folds and lamina of thyroid cartilage, abnormally enlarges to forms the air containing sac – Laryngocele.

questions.text: A Patient presenting with abdominal pain, blood in stools and a palpable mass on examination. A Barium Study was performed, probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The above shown image of barium study shows “Coiled spring appearance”, which is characterstic of Intussusception.

INTUSSUSCEPTION

  • It is a condition in which one segment of intestine telescopes inside of another, causing an intestinal obstruction.
  • It usually presents with nausea, vomiting, pain abdomen with blood in stools.
  • Palpable abdominal mass may be found on physical examination.
  • On X- ray :
    • Meniscus sign
  • On USG :
    • Target sign/ Doughnut Sign
  • On Barium :
    • Claw sign/ Pincer sign
    • Coiled spring appearance

questions.text: 35 year old male presenting with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, jaundice and fatigue underwent MRCP. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given MRCP image which shows multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing, along with given clinical features are suggestive of Primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

  • PSC is a chronic cholestatic syndrome that is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree, resulting in chronic cholestasis.
  • It leads to obliteration of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree, leading to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and liver failure.
  • Patient usually presents with fatigue, pruritis, and upper abdominal pain.
  • Jaundice and icterus may also be present
  • 70% cases are associated with IBD.
  • On MRCP, it shows shows multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing, known as “Prune tree appearance”.

questions.text: 22-year-old women presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after bring punched by her husband. Her blood pressure is 110/76, her pulse is 80 bpm, and her respiration rate is 24 breaths per minute. The best means to establish a diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Clinical picture of the patient in above question indicates that patient is hemodynamically stable. Therefore best mode of evaluation should be CT scan of abdomen to seen the extent of injury
  • Investigations in abdominal trauma is CECT
  • If the patient is hemodynamically stable and can be shifted –CECT scan
  • If the patients is hemodynamically unstable and cannot be shifted-ultrasound

questions.text: A 25 yr old asymptomatic male underwent chest radiography as part of a routine employment healthcheck up, the cxr suggests -
questions.solution: Asymmptomatic male with CXR showing a part of bowel between rt dome of diaphragm and liver is suggestive of Chiladiti sign and is a cause of pseudopneumoperitoneum
